objdescid.origination: John NicholsMichael Phillips argues that the printer was John Nichols ("William Blake and the 'Unincreasable Club': The Printing of *Poetical Sketches*, *Bulliten of the New York Public Library* 80 (1976): 6-18). According to Peter Ackroyd, the printer could have been John Flaxman's aunt, who had a small print shop where the first copies were produced (Ackroyd, *Blake*, 94). The print run was funded by Flaxman, the Reverend Anthony Stephen Mathew and his wife, Harriet. (*Writings* volume 2, 749)delineator, printer

objinfo.note: Mrs. Mathew may have persuaded her husband, the Rev. A. S. Mathew, to help her pay for the printing. He may have then written the advertisement (J.T. Smith, *Nollekens and His Times*, 1828, quoted in Bentley, *Blake Records*, 2nd ed. page 605).
objinfo.numberleaves: 38There are 38 leaves and 76 pages total. Blank pages are not reproduced here.
objinfo.medium: Typed with handwritten corrections in pen and ink.
objinfo.watermark: Chain lines, 2.8 cm apart. Bentley notes that the paper is defective and possibly from an odd lot (*Writings* volume 2, 1685).
objinfo.pennednumbers: 2-70Page numbers are at the outside corners of pages with running heads or, in the case of pages where the first line on a page is the title line, in the middle of the top margin in square brackets, except for pages 15 and 16, which are in round brackets.
objinfo.binding: Originally bound in light blue cloth boards with a red leather label on the spine. Rebound for Robert Hoe in Citron levant morocco, inside front cover is stamped with "THE CLUB BINDERY 1908". Page edges, frames on the covers, and title on the spine ("BLAKE/ - / POETICAL SKETCHES/ LOND./ 1783.") are gilt.

provenance.name: Huntington Library
provenance.note: Given by Blake to Charles Tulk in 1810; sold by Edward Duperner, Sotheby's, 20 June 1906, lot 937, £109 to B. F. Stevens; acquired by Robert Hoe, who rebound it in 1908; sold posthumously by Hoe to Anderson Auction Company, 1911, lot 389, to George D. Smith for the Huntington Library.

choice.orig: P O E T I C A L

lg.l: ByW.B.William Blake
L O N D O NLONDON:
Printed in the Year MDCCLXXXIII.

objnote.p: Mrs. Mathew may have persuaded her husband, the Rev. A. S. Mathew, to help pay for the printing. He may then have written the advertisement. (J. T. Smith, Nollekens and His Times, 1828, qtd. in Bentley, Blake Records, 2nd ed., page 605)

texthead.l: A D V E R T I S E M E N TADVERTISEMENT.

lg.l: T H ETHE following Sketches were the prod-production
duction of untutored youth, commenced
in his twelfth, and occasionally resumed by
the author till his twentieth year ; since
which time, his talents having been wholly
directed to the attainment of excellence in
his profession, he has been deprived of the
leisure requisite to such a revisal of these sheets,
as might have rendered them less unfit to
meet the public eye.
Conscious of the irregularities and defects
to be found in almost every page, his friends
have still believed that they possessed a poe-poetical
tical originality, which merited some respite
from oblivion. These their opinions remain,
however, to be now reproved or confirmed by
a less partial public.

texthead.l: T OTOS P R I N GSPRING.

lg.l: OT H O UTHOU, with dewy locks, who lookest
down
Thro'Through the clear windows of the morning ; turn
Thine angel eyes upon our western isle,
Which in full choir hails thy approach, O Spring !
The hills tell each other, and the list'ninglistening
ValliesValleys hear ; all our longing eyes are turned
Up to thy bright pavillionspavilions : issue forth,
And let thy holy feet visit our clime.
Come o'erover the eastern hills, and let our winds
Kiss thy perfumed garments ; let us taste
Thy morn and evening breath ; scatter thy pearls
Upon our love-sicklovesick land that mourns for thee.

choice.orig: S P R I N G.

lg.l: O deck her forth with they fair fingers ; pour
Thy soft kisses on her bosom ; and put
Thy golden crown upon her languish'dlanguished head,
Whose modest tresses were bound up for thee !

texthead.l: T OTOS U M M E RSUMMER.

lg.l: OT H O UTHOU, who passestpasses thro'through our valliesvalleys in
Thy strength, curb thy fierce steeds, allay
the heat
That flames from their large nostrils ! thou, O
Summer,
OftOften pitched'stpitched here thy golden tent, and oft
Beneath our oaks hast slept, while we beheld
With joy, thy ruddy limbs and flourishing hair.In copy W, "flourishing" is emended to "flowing" in an unBlakelike hand (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 750n).
Beneath our thickest shades we oftoften have heard
Thy voice, when noon upon his fervid car
Rode o'erover the deep of heaven; beside our springs
Sit down, and in our mossy valliesvalleys, on
Some bank beside a river clear, throw thy
Silk draperies off, and rush into the stream :
Our valliesvalleys love the Summer in his pride.
Our bards are fam'dfamed who strike the silver wire :
Our youth are bolder than the southern swains :
Our maidens fairer in the sprightly dance :
We lack not songs, nor instruments of joy,
Nor echoes sweet, nor waters clear as heaven,
Nor laurel wreaths against the sultry heat.

texthead.l: T OTOA U T U M NAUTUMN.

lg.l: OA U T U M NAUTUMN, laden with fruit, and stained
With the blood of the grape, pass not, but sit
Beneath my shady roof, there thou may'stmayestmay rest,
And tune thy jolly voice to my fresh pipe ;
And all the daughters of the year shall dance !
Sing now the lusty song of fruits and flowers.
" The narrow bud opens her beauties to
" The sun, and love runs in her thrilling veins;
" Blossoms hang round the brows of morning, and
" Flourish down the bright cheek of modest eve,
" Till clust'ringclustering Summer breaks forth into singing,
" And feather'dfeathered clouds strew flowers round her
" head.
" The spirits of the air live on the smells
" Of fruit; and joy, with pinions light, roves round
" The gardens, or sits singing in the trees."
Thus sang the jolly Autumn as he sat,
Then rose, girded himself, and o'erover the bleak
Hills fled from our sight; but left his golden load.

texthead.l: T OTOW I N T E RWINTER.

lg.l: OW I N T E RWINTER ! bar thine adamantine doors :
The north is thine ; there hast thou built thy
dark
Deep-founded habitation. Shake not thy roofs,
Nor bend thy pillars with thine iron car.
He hears me not, but o'erover the yawning deep
In ribbed steel, I dare not lift mine eyes ;
For he hath rear'dreared his sceptre o'erover the world.
Lo! now the direful monster, whose skin clings
To his strong bones, strides o'erover the groaning rocks :
He withers all in silence, and in his handThe "in" is deleted in copies B, C, E, F, O, Q, S, T, V, W, and Y (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 752n) (Essick 177).
Unclothes the earth, and freezes up frail life.
He takes his seat upon the cliffs, the mariner
Cries in vain. Poor little wretch ! that deal'stdeals
With storms ; till heaven smiles, and the monster
Is driv'ndriven yelling to his caves beneath mount Hecla.

texthead.l: E V E N I N GEVENINGS T A RSTAR.

lg.l: T H O UTHOUfair-hair'dfair-haired angel of the evening,
Now, whilstwhile the sun rests on the mountains,In copy Q, "whilst" is emended to "while" (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 752n) (Erdman 847).
light
Thy bright torch of love ; thy radiant crown
Put on, and smile upon our evening bed!
Smile on our loves ; and, while thou drawestdraw the
Blue curtains of the sky, scatter thy silver dew
On every flower that shuts its sweet eyes
In timely sleep. Let thy west wind sleep on
The lake ; speak silence with thy glimmering eyes,
And wash the dusk with silver. Soon, full soon,
Dost thou withdraw ; then the wolf rages wide,
And the lion glares thro'through the dun forest :
The fleeces of our flocks are cover'dcovered with
Thy sacred dew : protect them with thine in-influence
fluence.

texthead.l: T OTOM O R N I N GMORNING.

lg.l: OH O L YHOLY virgin ! clad in purest white,
Awake the dawn that sleeps in heaven ; let light
Rise from the chambers of the east, and bring
The honied dew that comethcomes on waking day.
O radiant morning, salute the sun,
Rouz'dRoused like a huntsman to the chacechase ; and, with
Thy buskin'dbuskined feet, appear upon our hills.

texthead.l: F A I RFAIRE L E N O RELENOR.

lg.l: T H ETHE bell struck one, and shook the silent
tower ;
The graves give up their dead : fair ElenorIn the margin of copy F, a "contemporary hand" has emended "give" to "gave" in ink (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 753n).
Walk'dWalked by the castle gate, and looked in.
A hollow groan ran thro'through the dreary vaults.
She shriek'dshrieked aloud, and sunk upon the steps
On the cold stone her pale cheeks. Sickly smellsThe "s" in "cheeks" is deleted in copies C, E, Q, S, V, and Y (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 753n) (Erdman 847)(Essick 177).
Of death, issue as from a sepulchre,
And all is silent but the sighing vaults.
Chill death withdraws his hand, and she revives ;
Amaz'dAmazed, she finds herself upon her feet,
And, like a ghost, thro'through narrow passages
Walking, feeling the cold walls with her hands.
Fancy returns, and now she thinks of bones,
And grinning skulls, and corruptible death,
Wrap'dWrapped in his shroud ; and now, fancies she hears
Deep sighs, and sees pale sickly ghosts gliding.
At length, no fancy, but reality
Distracts her. A rushing sound, and the feet
Of one that fled, approaches—EllenElenor stood,
Like a dumb statue, froze to stone with fear.

texthead.l: 8F A I RFAIRE L E N O RELENOR.

lg.l: The wretch approaches, crying, " The deed is
" done ;
" Take this, and send it by whom thou wilt send ;
" It is my life—send it to Elenor :—
"He's dead, and howling after me for blood!
" Take this," he cry'dcried ; and thrust into her arms
A wet napkin, wrap'dwrapped about ; then rush'drushed
Past, howling : she receiv'dreceived into her arms
Pale death, and follow'dfollowed on the wings of fear.
They pass'dpassed swift thro'through the outer gate ; the wretch,
Howling, leap'dleapedleapt o'erover the wall into the moat,
Stifling in mud. Fair EllenElenorpass'dpassed the bridge,
And heard a gloomy voice cry, " Is it done?"
As the deerdear wounded EllenElenor flew over
The pathless plain ; as the arrows that fly
By night ; destruction flies, and strikes in darkness,
She fled from fear, till at her house arriv'darrived.
Her maids await her ; on her bed she falls,
That bed of joy, where erst her lord hath press'dpressed :
" Ah, woman's fear!" she cry'dcried ; " Ah, cursed
" duke!
" Ah, my dear lord! ah, wretched Elenor!
" My lord was like a flower upon the brows
" Of lusty May ! Ah, life as frail as flower!

texthead.l: F A I RFAIRE L E N O RELENOR.9

lg.l: " O ghastly death ! withdraw thy cruel hand,
" Seek'stSeekest thou that flow'rflower to deck thy horrid
" temples?
" My lord was like a star, in highest heav'nheaven
" Drawn down to earth by spells and wickedness ;
" My lord was like the opening eyes of day,
" When western winds creep softly o'erover the flowers :
" But he is darken'ddarkened ; like the summer's noon,
" The breath of heaven dwelt among his leaves.
" O Elenor, weak woman, fill'dfilled with woe !"
Thus having spoke, she raised up her head,
And saw the bloody napkin by her side,
Which in her arms she brought ; and now, tenfold
More terrified, saw it unfold itself.
Her eyes were fix'dfixed; the bloody cloth unfolds,
Disclosing to her sight the murder'dmurdered head
Of her dear lord, all ghastly pale, clotted
With gory blood ; it groan'dgroaned, and thus is spake :
" O Elenor, I am thy husband's head,In copies B, D, E, F, O, Q, S, and W, "I am" is erased and replaced with "behold" (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 755n) (Erdman 847).
" Who, sleeping on the stones of yonder tower,
" Was 'reftbereft of life by the accursed duke!
" A hired villain turn'dturned my sleep to death !
" O Elenor, beware the curs'dcursed duke,
" O give not him thy hand, now I am dead ;

texthead.l: 10F A I RFAIRE L E N O RELENOR.

lg.l: " He seeks thy love ; who, coward, in the night,
" Hired a villain to bereave my life."
She took the gory head up in her arms ;
She hugg'dhugged it to her breast, and groan'dgroaned her last.
H O WHOW sweet I roam'droamed from field to field,
And tasted all the summer's pride,
'Till I the prince of love beheld,
Who in the sunny beams did glide !
He shew'dshowed me lilies for my hair,
And blushing roses for my brow ;
He led me through his gardens fair,
Where all his golden pleasures grow.
With sweet May dews my wings were wet,
He caught me in his silken net,
And shut me in his golden cage.
He loves to sit and hear me sing,
Then, laughing, sports and plays with me ;
Then stretches out my golden wing,
And mocks my loss of liberty.
M YMY silks and fine array,
My smiles and languish'dlanguished air,
By love are driv'ndriven away ;
And mournful lean Despair
Brings me yew to deck my grave :
Such end true lovers have.
His face is fair as heav'nheaven,
When springing buds unfold ;
O why to him was'twas itgiv'ngiven,
Whose heart is wintry cold ?
His breast is love's all-worship'dall-worshipped tomb,
Where all love's pilgrims come.
Bring me an axe and spade,
Bring me a winding sheet ;
When I my grave have made,
Let winds and tempests beat :
Then down I'll lie, as cold as clay.
True love doth pass away !
L O V ELOVE and harmony combine,
And around our souls intwine,
While thy branches mix with mine,
And our roots together join.
Joys upon our branches sit,
Chirping loud, and singing sweet ;
Like gentle streams beneath our feet
Innocence and virtue meet.
Thou the golden fruit dost bear,
I am clad in flowers fair ;
Thy sweet boughs perfume the air,
And the turtle buildeth there.
There she sits and feeds her young,
Sweet I hear her mournful song ;
And thy lovely leaves among,

There is love : I hear heris tongue.In copies C, Q, and V, "her" is changed to "his" by writing over the printed letters in pen and ink (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 757n) (Erdman 847)(Essick 177).
There his charming nest doth lay,
There he sleeps the night away ;
There he sports along the day,
And doth among our branches play.
IL O V ELOVE the jocund dance,
The softly-breathing song,
Where innocent eyes do glance,
And where lisps the maiden's tongue.
I love the laughing vale,
I love the echoing hill,
Where mirth does never fail,
And the jolly swain laughs his fill.In copy F, "his fill" is altered to "still" with ink (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 758n).
I love the pleasant cot,
I love the innocent bow'rbower,
Where white and brown is our lot,
Or fruit in the mid-daymidday hour.
I love the oaken seat,
Beneath the oaken tree,
Where all the old villagers meet,
And laugh our sports to see.
I love our neighboursneighbors all,
But, Kitty, I better love thee ;
And love them I ever shall ;
But thou art all to me.
M E M O R YMEMORY, hither come,
And tune your merry notes ;
And, while upon the wind,
Your music floats,
I'll pore upon the stream,
Where sighing lovers dream,
And fish for fancies as they pass
Within the watery glass.
I'll drink of the clear stream,
And hear the linnet's song ;
And there I'll lie and dream
The day along :
And, when night comes, I'll go
To places fit for woe ;
Walking along the darken'ddarkened valley,
With silent Melancholy.
T H ETHE wild winds weep,
And the night is a-cold ;
Come hither, Sleep,
And my griefs unfold :In copies B, E, F, O, Q, S, and W, "unfold" is changed to "infold" (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 759n) (Erdman 847).
But lo ! the morning peeps
Over the eastern steeps,

And the rustling beds of dawnIn copies B, C, D, E, F, O, Q, S, T, V, and W, "beds" has been struck through and "birds" written above it in ink (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 759n) (Erdman 847)(Essick 177).
The earth do scorn.
Lo ! To the vault
Of paved heaven,
With sorrow fraught
My notes are driven :
They strike the ear of night,
Make weep the eyes of day ;
They make mad the roaring winds,
And with tempests play.
Like a fiend in a cloud
With howling woe,
After night I do croudcrowd,
And with night will go ;
I turn my back to the east,
From whence comforts have increas'dincreased ;
For light doth seize my brain
With frantic pain.
F R E S HFRESH from the dewy hill, the merry year
Smiles on my head, and mounts his flaming
car ;
Round my young brows the laurel wreathes a shade,
And rising glories beam around my head.
My feet are wing'dwinged, while o'erover the dewy lawn,
I meet my maiden, risen like the morn :
Oh bless those holy feet, like angels' feet ;
Oh bless those limbs, beaming with heav'nlyheavenly light !
Like as an angel glitt'ringglittering in the sky,
In times of innocence, and holy joy ;
The joyful shepherd stops his grateful song,
To hear the music of an angel's tongue.
So when she speaks, the voice of Heaven I hear :
So when we walk, nothing impure comes near;
Each field seems Eden, and each calm retreat ;
Each village seems the haunt of holy feet.
But that sweet village where my black-ey'dblack-eyed maid,
Closes her eyes in sleep beneath night's shade :
Whene'erWhenever I enter, more than mortal fire
Burns in my soul, and does my song inspire.
W H E NWHEN early morn walks forth in sober
grey ;
Then to my black ey'deyed maid I haste away,
When evening sits beneath her dusky bow'rbower,
And gently sighs away the silent hour ;
The village bell alarms, away I go ;
And the vale darkens at my pensive woe.
To that sweet village, where my black ey'deyed maid
Doth drop a tear beneath the silent shade,
I turn my eyes ; and, pensive as I go,
Curse my black stars, and bless my pleasing woe.In the margin of copy F, "black" is changed to "ill" in ink in a contemporary hand (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 761n).
OftOften when the summer sleeps among the trees,
Whisp'ringWhispering faint murmurs to the scanty breeze,
I walk the village round ; if at her side
A youth doth walk in stolen joy and pride,
I curse my stars in bitter grief and woe,
That made my love so high, and me so low.
O should she e'erever prove false, his limbs I'd tear,
And throw all pity on the burning air ;
I'd curse bright fortune for my mixed lot,
And then I'd die in peace, and be forgot.

texthead.l: T OTOT H ETHEM U S E SMUSES.

lg.l: W H E T H E RWHETHER on Ida's shady brow,
Or in the chambers of the East,
The chambers of the sun, that now
Whether in Heav'nHeaven ye wander fair,
Or the greeengreen corners of the earth,
Or the blue regions of the air,
Where the melodious winds have birth ;
Whether on chrystalcrystal rocks ye rove,
Beneath the bosom of the sea
Wand'ringWandering in many a coral grove,
Fair Nine, forsaking Poetry !
How have you left the antientancient love
That bards of old enjoy'denjoyed in you !
The languid strings do scarcely move !
The sound is forc'dforced, the notes are few !

texthead.l: G W I NGWIN,K I N GKINGO FOFN O R W A YNORWAY.

lg.l: C O M ECOME, Kings, and listen to my song,
When Gwin, the son of Nore,
Over the nations of the North
His cruel sceptrescepter bore :
The Nobles of the land did feed
Upon the hungry Poor ;
They tear the poor man's lamb, and drive
The needy from their door !
The land is desolate ; our wives
And children cry for bread ;
Arise, and pull the tyrant down ;
Let Gwin be humbled.
Gordred the giant rous'droused himself
From sleeping in his cave ;
He shook the hills, and in the clouds
The troubl'dtroubled banners wave.
Beneath them roll'drolled, like tempests black,
Like lions' whelps, roaring abroad,
Seeking their nightly food.
Down Bleron's hills they dreadful rush,
Their cry ascends the clouds ;
The trampling horse, and clanging arms

Like rushing mighty floods !In copy W, "and clanging arms Like rushing" is deleted and replaced by "[Th]eir hauberks / [word trimmed off; ?(flas)h;] the tram / [p]ling horse / Rush on like mighty floods" in an unBlakelike hand (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 763n).
Their wives and children, weeping loud,
Follow in wild array,
Howling like ghosts, furious as wolves
In the bleak wintry day.
" Pull down the tyrant to the dust,
" Let Gwin be humbled,"
They cry ; " and let ten thousand lives
" Pay for the tyrant's head."
From tow'rtower to tow'rtower the watchmen cry,
" O Gwyn, the son of Nore,
" Arouse thyself! the nations black,
" Like clouds, come rolling o'erover !"
Gwin rear'dreared his shield, his palace shakes,
His chiefs come rushing round ;
Each, like an awful thunder cloud,
With voice of solemn sound :
Like reared stones around a grave
They stand around the King ;
Then suddenly each seiz'dseized his spear,
And clashing steel does ring.

texthead.l: K I N GKINGO FOFN O R W A YNORWAY. 21

lg.l: The husbandman does leave his plow,
The merchant binds his brows in steel,
And leaves the trading shore :
The shepherd leaves his mellow pipe,
And sounds the trumpet shrill ;
The workman throws his hammer down
To heave the bloody bill.
Like the tall ghost of Barraton,
Who sports in stormy sky,
Gwin leads his host as black as night,
When pestilence does fly.
With horses and with chariots—
And all his spearmen bold,
March to the sound of mournful song,
Like clouds around him roll'drolled.
Gwin lifts his hand—the nations halt ;
" Prepare for war," he cries—
Gordred appears !—his frowning brow
Troubles our northern skies.
The armies stand, like balances
Held in th'the Almighty's hand ;—
" Gwin, thou hast filldfilled thy measure up,
"Thou'rtThou art swept from out the land."
And now the raging armies rush'drushed,
Like warring mighty seas ;
The Heav'nsHeavens are shook with roaring war,
The dust ascends the skies !
Earth smokes with blood, and groans, and shakes,
To drink her childrens' gore,
A sea of blood ; nor can the eye
See to the trembling shore !
And on the verge of this wild sea
Famine and death doth cry ;
The cries of women and of babes
Over the field doth fly.
The King is seen raging afar,
With all his men of might ;
Like blazing comets, scattering death
Thro'Through the red fev'rousfeverous night.
Beneath his arm like sheep they die,
And groan upon the plain ;
The battle faints, and bloody men
Fight upon hills of slain.
Now death is sick, and riven men
Labour and toil for life ;
Steed rolls on steed, and shield on shield,
Sunk in this sea of strife !

texthead.l: K I N GKINGO FOFN O R W A YNORWAY.23

lg.l: The god of war is drunk with blood,
The earth doth faint and fail ;
The stench of blood makes sick the heav'nsheavens ;
Ghosts glut the throat of hell !
O what have Kings to answer for,
Before that awful throne !
When thousand deaths for vengeance cry,
And ghosts accusing groan !
Like blazing comets in the sky,
That shake the stars of light,
Which drop like fruit unto the earth,
Thro'Through the fierce burning night;
Like these did Gwin and Gordred meet,
And the first blow decides ;
Down from the brow unto the breast
Gordred his head divides!
Gwin fell; the Sons of Norway fled,
The rest did fill the vale of death,
For them the eagles strive.
The river Dorman roll'drolled their blood
Into the northern sea ;
Who mourn'dmourned his sons, and overwhelm'doverwhelmed
The pleasant south country.

texthead.l: I M I T A T I O NIMITATIONOFOFS P E N C E RSpenser.

lg.l: G O L D E NGOLDEN Apollo, that thro'through heaven wide
Scatter'stScatters the rays of light, and truth's beams!
In lucent words my darkling verses dight,
And wash my earthy mind in thy clear streams,In copy F, "And" is deleted and "thou" is inserted in ink in a contemporary hand after the word "wash" (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 766n).
That wisdom may descend in fairy dreams :
All while the jocund hours in thy train
Scatter their fancies at thy poet's feet ;
And when thou yields to night thy wide domain,In copy F, "yields" was corrected to "yield'st" in ink by a contemporary hand (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 766n).
Let rays of truth enlightenlighten his sleeping brain.
For brutish Pan in vain might thee assay
With tinkling sounds to dash thy nervous verse,
Sound without sense ; yet in his rude affray,
(For ignorance is Folly's leesingleasing nurse,
And love of Folly needs none others curse ;)The "s" of "others" is deleted in copies T and V (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 767n) (Erdman 847).
Midas the praise hath gain'dgained of lengthen'dlengthened cares,In copies F, Q, and T, "cares" has been amended in ink to "eares" (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 767n) (Erdman 847).
For which himself might deem him ne'ernever the
worse
To sit in council with his modern peers,
And judge of tinkling rhimesrhymes, and elegances terse.
And thou, Mercurius, that with winged brow
Dost mount aloft into the yielding sky,
And thro'throughHeav'n'sHeaven's halls thy airy flight dost throw,
Entering with holy feet to where on high
Jove weighs the counsel of futurity ;
Then, laden with eternal fate, dost go
Down, like a falling star, from autumn sky,
And o'erover the surface of the silent deep dost fly.
If thou arrivestarrive at the sandy shore,
Where nought but envious hissing adders dwell,
Thy golden rod, thrown on the dusty floor,
Can charm to harmony with potent spell ;
Such is sweet Eloquence, that does dispel
Envy and Hate, that thirst for human gore :
And cause in sweet society to dwell
Vile savage minds that lurk in lonely cell.
O Mercury, assist my lab'ringlaboring sense,
That round the circle of the world wou'dwould fly !
As the wing'dwinged eagle scorns the tow'rytowery fence
Of Alpine hills round his high aeryaerieeyrie,
And searches thro'through the corners of the sky,
Sports in the clouds to hear the thunder's sound,
And see the winged lightnings as they fly,
Then, bosom'dbosomed in an amber cloud, around
Plumes his wide wings, and seeks Sol's palace high.
And thou, O warrior, maid invincible,In copy Q, "warrior, maid invincible" was changed to "warrior maid, invincible" (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 768n) (Erdman 847).
Arm'dArmed with the terrors of Almighty Jove !
Pallas, Minerva, maiden terrible,
Lov'stLovest thou to walk the peaceful solemn grove,
In solemn gloom of branches interwove ?
Or bear'stbearest thy Egis o'erover the burning field,
Where, like the sea, the waves of battle move ?
Or have thy soft piteous eyes beheld
The weary wanderer thro'through the desert rove ?
Or does th'the afflicted man thy heav'nlyheavenly bosom move ?

texthead.l: B L I N DBLIND-M A N'SB U F FBUFF.

lg.l: W H E NWHEN silver Snow decks Susan's cloathsclothes,
And jewel hangs at th'the shepherd's nose,
The blushing bank is all my care,
With hearth so red, and walls so fair ;
" Heap the sea-coal ; come, heap it higher,
" The oaken log lay on the fire :"
The well-wash'dwell-washed stools, a circling row,
With lad and lass, how fair the show !
The merry can of nut-brown ale,
The laughing jest, the love-sicklovesick tale,
'Till tir'dtired of chat, the game begins,
The lasses prick the lads with pins ;
Roger from Dolly twitch'dtwitched the stool,
She falling, kiss'dkissed the ground, poor fool !
She blush'dblushed so red, with side-long glance
At hob-nail Dick, who griev'dgrieved the chance.
But now for Blind-man's Buff they call ;
Of each incumbrance clear the hall—
Jenny her silken 'kerchiefhandkerchief folds,
Now laughing, flops, with " Silence! hush!"
And Peggy Pout gives Sam a push.—
The Blind-man's arms, extended wide,
Sam slips between ;—" O woe betide
Thee, clumsy Will !"—but titt'ringtittering Kate
Is pen'dpenned up in the corner strait !
And now Will's eyes beheld the play,
He thought his face was t'otherthe other way.—
" Now, Kitty, now ; what chance hast thou,
" Roger so near thee, Trips ; I vow!
She catches him—then Roger ties
His own head up—but not his eyes ;
For thro'through the slender cloth he sees,
And runs at Sam, who flips with ease
His clumsy hold ; and, dodging round,
Sukey is tumbled on the ground !—
" See what it is to play unfair !
" Where cheating is, there's mischief there."
But Roger still pursues the chacechase,—
" He sees! he sees! cries softly Grace ;
" O Roger, thou, unskill'dunskilled in art,
" Must, surer bound, go thro'through thy part !"
Now Kitty, pert, repeats the rhymes,
And Roger turns him round three times ;
Then pauses ere he starts—but Dick
Was mischief bent upon a trick :
Down on his hands and knees he lay,
Directly in the Blind-man's way—
Then cries out, " Hem !" Hodge heard, and ran
But down he came.—Alas, how frail
Our best of hopes, how soon they fail !
With crimson drops he stains the ground,
Confusion startles all around !
Poor piteous Dick supports his head,
And fain would cure the hurt he made ;
But Kitty hasted with a key,
And down his back they strait convey
The cold relief—the blood is stay'dstayed,
And Hodge again holds up his head.
Such are the fortunes of the game,
And those who play should stop the same
By wholesome laws ; such as all those
Who on the blinded man impose.In copy Q, "impose." was changed to "impose," (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 770n) (Erdman 847).
Stand in his stead as long a-goneIn copy Q, a semicolon was inserted after "stead" (Bentley, Writings volume 2, page 770n) (Erdman 847).
When men were first a nation grown ;
Lawless they liv'dlived—till wantonness
And liberty began t'to increase ;
And one man lay in another's way,
Then laws were made to keep fair play.
